snippet: There’s finally a sense that women have become a significant part of Afghanistan’s political life, but many fear the gains could be reversed if extremists retake power or Western aid dwindles.
abstract: More Afghan women than ever before are running for elected office, with 300 in contention for provincial seats around the country; former Bamian Province Gov Habiba Sarobi is also running as the first vice-presidential female candidate on a leading national ticket; finally there is a sense that women have become a significant part of Afghan political life, but fear exists that gains could be reversed if extremists come back into power, or if Western aid dwindles.
lead_paragraph: There’s finally a sense that women have become a significant part of Afghanistan’s political life, but many fear the gains could be reversed if extremists retake power or Western aid dwindles.

headline.main: Afghan Women See Hope in the Ballot Box
